title: Boy, 8, scratched lines into skin to ‘look whiter’ after being called ‘N-word’
text:

A schoolboy who was repeatedly called the n-word at school has told how he used to scratch white lines into his skin in a bid to look whiter.

Finley Sullivan, 8, admits he would go days without moisturising his skin so it would "go dry and dusty and would appear lighter".

Mum Colleen Robinson says the racist abuse became so bad her son would go outside and stare at the floor in fear of being abused.

The schoolboy, from Par, Cornwall, was born in Kettering, Northamptonshire with his dad born in Uganda and his mum in Dover, Kent.

His dad left Uganda aged 20 during the Amin regime, fleeing to nearby Rwanda.

He managed to escape the 1994 genocide - which saw between 500,000-one million people slaughtered - with help from The Red Cross, which helped him settle in the UK.

(Image: Colleen Robinson /SWNS.COM)

Finley said: "People say the N-word and that I should go back to Africa where I belong.

"The first time it happened I was in year one.

"A kid called me a stupid African and hit me.

"Sometimes I feel sad and angry. I stopped moisturising so my skin would go dry and dusty and I'd look lighter for school.

"I scratched white lines into my skin, too, to try and look whiter.

"People stare at me and touch my hair without asking too.

"It just makes me feel sad and angry."

(Image: Colleen Robinson /SWNS.COM)

Devastated Mum Colleen said the abuse is not just in the playground.

She said: "I had a new-born in a pram. I told the kids to keep walking, that the men were making noises because mummy looks silly.

"Fin said, 'I know they were making the noises at me because I look like a monkey'.

“It seems Brexit has given everyone an excuse to bring out their worst side.

"We want to leave but my husband has a business down here so it isn’t as easy as that. One boy who is 13 has been prosecuted.

"I went to his mum and told her I was going to the police and she said that she was glad because he’s out of control.

"I'm just sick of people not evolving. It's like going back in time."

(Image: Colleen Robinson /SWNS.COM)

She is calling for more black history teaching in Cornish schools in a bid to combat racial intolerance.

She said: "There’s very little racial diversity here so it’s like you’ve got to hide away and get on with it.

“We’re hoping by speaking out that others who are the victims of racial abuse down here will stand up and know they’re not alone.”

But despite the years of abuse Finley has recently starting to learn the ukulele in the hope of one day being able to hold a music festival promoting racial diversity in Cornwall.

He said: "I like being mixed race. It's when people are racist to me I don't like it, it makes me feel I don't fit in."
description: Finley Sullivan, from Par, Cornwall, has been repeatedly taunted by cruel classmates who have told him to 'go home to Africa'
